Award.AwardTitle: New Perspectives on Wave Propagation in Random Media
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
Measurements of the spectrum of the microwave field pattern at the output surface and on a line along the length of disordered samples generated by a source moved to points on a grid over the sample's input surface will provide a comprehensive picture of waves transport. Related measurements will be carried out using laser light and a spatial light modulator and CCD camera. The analyses of these measurements will be supplemented with finite difference time domain numerical simulations. This research will advance four distinct perspectives on wave transport and the relationships between them: the spatial structure of (1) modes and (2) transmission eigenchannels, as well as the variation with position of (3) the local diffusion coefficient, and (4) the field speckle pattern for both diffusive and localized waves. Wave statistics determined in single samples will guide applications to focusing, imaging, and enhanced transmission in random systems. The joint experimental, theoretical and numerical study of fundamental and applied aspects of propagation using microwave radiation and light will provide and ideal learning experience for the undergraduate, graduate, and high school students and the postdoctoral fellow involved in this research. The work will strengthen the photonics initiative at CUNY and foster photonic technological in the New York City area.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
The manner in which waves propagate in random media affects our ability to communicate and image and to create electronic and photonics devices. The study of waves in multiply-scattering systems is all the more challenging because of the twin difficulties of probing the interior of scattering samples and measuring the full scattered field. In this project, we will measure the wave pattern generated by sources of microwave radiation and light at various positions on the output of disordered samples as well as microwave radiation in the interior of such samples. This full set of measurements will allow us to determine the natural modes of oscillation as well as the specific transmission channels for waves in each random sample as well as the position dependent flux and intensity of the wave and the nature of fluctuations of intensity throughout the sample. The work will enable optimal focusing through and within random systems and will yield nearly complete transmission even in ordinarily opaque systems. The use of both microwave and laser measurements for challenging fundamental and applied problems will advance the education and careers of graduate students, undergraduates, high school students and a postdoctoral fellow involved in the research. The success of this work will strengthen the CUNY Photonic Center established to enhance the technological base of the New York City metropolitan area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All physical phenomena involve waves—either classical waves, such as light and sound, or quantum mechanical waves, such as electrons and atoms. Since perfectly ordered structures are the exception rather than the rule, the way waves scatter from and spread within disordered media influences our lives in many ways. It affects our ability to communicate and image and to create electronic and photonics devices. Despite the diversity of wave interactions, statistical properties of scattering from disordered systems depends upon a single parameter which describes the closeness to the threshold between freely diffusing and spatially localized waves trapped by wave interference. The single-parameter hypothesis was posited for one-dimensional electronic systems in 1980, but the first confirmation of this theory was made in our recent measurements of transmittance of microwave radiation in a three dimensional environment. Our recent work has extended the scope of the universal description of wave propagation from waves scattered from opaque samples to waves in the interior of the sample. At the same time, we have found unanticipated limits to such a universal description.

 

We find in computer simulations and microwave measurements that the profiles of the energy density within the medium of natural channels of transmission, called transmission eigenchannels are universal in that they can be expressed in terms of a single parameter—the ratio of the sample length to the localization length within which waves are trapped in a sample. We find that for the completely transmitting eigenchannel the intensity is peaked in the middle of the sample while for low-transmission eigenchannels, the energy fall rapids towards the output. The knowledge of the relationship between the intensity profiles and transmission makes it possible to deposit energy selectively in the interior of random samples. We show that the contribution of each transmission eigenchannel to the density of states (DOS) is the rate of change with frequency of the phase of the eigenchannel. The DOS is the number modes of oscillation of the wave within the sample. We show that it is equal to the energy deposited in the sample due to energy flowing towards the sample in all channels. Unexpectedly, we find that the expression for the intensity profiles for different transmission eigenvalues in multiply scattering media holds even in samples thinner than the typical distance in which the wave scatters. We have found a sharp transition in the probability distribution of transmission eigenvalues as the reflectivity on one of the surfaces increases for reflectivity high enough that transmission can no longer be complete.

 

For localized waves in random dielectric samples, we find that the local DOS drops sharply inside the sample. This is contrary to the foundational view that the local DOS is uniform in random samples and is independent of the degree of spatial localization. These results may provide novel ways for trapping radiation or of isolating a region from its surroundings.

 

Because propagation through random systems is inherently statistical, the focus of statistics has been on propagation in collections of statistically equivalent random systems. We have shown that a rich statistics exists even within a single sample in terms of the number of the effective number of eigenchannels that contribute significantly towards the transmittance. We have further shown that the same parameter gives the contrast in focusing of transmitted waves both for a steady and pulsed incident radiation.

 

We have found the connection between the transmission eigenchannels and the modes within the sample. Modes that are near resonance with the incident wave contribute to high transmission eigenchannels and provide a delayed response to incident radiation. In contrast, off-resonance modes contribute to low-transmission eigenchannels and respond promptly to an incident pulse. This provides methods for most efficiently exciting the sample and for controlling the time evolution of energy within the sample.

 

This work is of broad application to energy storage and imaging in and through disordered media with applications to biomedical imaging, resource exploration, telecommunications, photothermal therapy and random lasing.

We have demonstrated that it is possible to send microwave radiation along arbitrary paths in a two-dimensional structure without any scattering or additional time delay relative to ballistic propagation. This is accomplished in a reconfigurable photonic topological insulator in which the copper structure functions as a synthetic gauge field analogous to the quantum spin Hall effect. Extending these ideas to the visible would make possible perfect interconnects in photonic integrated circuits.

Three doctoral students have been involved in all facets of this research. One of them received his Ph.D. in 2014 and is now a research scientist at Chiral Photonics, Inc. in New Jersey. Four undergraduates and seven high school students have also been involved in the research. The experience the students obtain in carrying out computer simulations and microwave studies of problems with applications in many areas gives them a sound foundation in research.
